meanings.definition: To affirm or assert (something) about the subject of a sentence.
meanings.sent1: She will predicate her decision on the weather forecast.
meanings.sent2: The teacher asked the students to predicate their answers on the text they read.
meanings.sent3: The cat seemed to predicate its nap time on the sunbeam's location.
meanings.sent4: His success seemed to predicate on his dedication and hard work.
meanings.sent5: The outcome will predicate on the team's cooperation and effort.

meanings.definition: The part of a sentence or clause containing a verb and stating something about the subject.
meanings.sent1: In the sentence, the predicate is 'jumped over the fence'.
meanings.sent2: The predicate of the statement 'She sings beautifully' is 'sings beautifully'.
meanings.sent3: The predicate of the story was the unexpected twist at the end.
meanings.sent4: His success story had a strong predicate that captured the audience's attention.
meanings.sent5: The predicate of the play revealed the true intentions of the main character.
